problem_prompt: Solve the following problem. Let $S_i$ be the set of all integers $n$ such that $100i\leq n < 100(i + 1)$. For example, $S_4$ is the set ${400,401,402,\ldots,499}$. How many of the sets $S_0, S_1, S_2, \ldots, S_{999}$ do not contain a perfect square?
solution:
The difference between consecutive squares is $(x + 1)^2 - x^2 = 2x + 1$, which means that all squares above $50^2 = 2500$ are more than $100$ apart.
Then the first $26$ sets ($S_0,\cdots S_{25}$) each have at least one perfect square. Also, since $316^2 < 100000$ (which is when $i = 1000$), there are $316 - 50 = 266$ other sets after $S_{25}$ that have a perfect square.
There are $1000 - 266 - 26 = \boxed{708}$ sets without a perfect square.
gpt_response:
A perfect square has the form $m^2$ for some integer $m$. Notice that $m^2 < 100(i+1)$ if and only if $m<10\sqrt{i+1}$. Therefore, $S_i$ contains a perfect square if and only if there exists an integer $m$ such that $m^2\in S_i$, or $m^2\geq 100i$ and $m^2< 100(i+1)$. This is equivalent to $m\geq 10\sqrt{i}$ and $m< 10\sqrt{i+1}$, which is true if and only if $10\lfloor \sqrt{i+1}\rfloor \geq 10\lfloor \sqrt{i}\rfloor+1$.

We will now determine for which values of $i$ the above inequality holds. Clearly, $i$ can be expressed as $m^2+k$ for some $m,k\in\mathbb{N}$ with $0\leq k\leq 2m$ (since $i<1000$). Then, the above inequality simplifies to $10m\geq 10\lfloor \sqrt{m^2+k+1}\rfloor +1$ or $10m\geq 10m+1$ which is clearly not true. Therefore, for any $0\leq i<1000$, the set $S_i$ does not contain a perfect square.

Hence, all of the sets $S_0, S_1, S_2, \ldots, S_{999}$ do not contain a perfect square. There are $\boxed{1000}$ such sets.

We will now determine for which values of $i$ the above inequality holds. Clearly, $i$ can be expressed as $m^2+k$ for some $m,k\in\mathbb{N}$ with $0\leq k\leq 2m$ (since $i<1000$). Then, the above inequality simplifies to $10m\geq 10\lfloor \sqrt{m^2+k+1}\rfloor +1$ or $10m\geq 10m+1$ which is clearly not true.
